title: North Carolina denies Jaws problem after seventh shark attack
text:
North Carolina denies Jaws problem after seventh shark attack 2 July 2015 Save 
Authorities in North Carolina have denied they have a Jaws problem following a seventh shark attack in the space of a month. 
The most recent attack on Wednesday occurred off Ocracoke Island when a 68-year-old man had his hands bitten in waist-deep water around 30 yards off shore. He was flown to hospital for treatment. 
His was the latest in a string of attacks, which started last month when a teenage girl suffered minor injuries and damage to her surfboard in an attack. 
Since then two teenagers have had arms bitten off in separate incidents while Wednesday’s attack was the third in the space of less than a week on the North Carolina coast. 
A teenager was left in a critical condition on Saturday after he was bitten on the calf, buttocks and both hands at a beach on the Cape Hatteras National Seashore. 
A day earlier a 47-year-old man suffered injuries to his right leg and lower back in a separate attack. 
Yesterday’s attack comes just days before the July 4 weekend and has prompted calls for the authorities to close the state’s beaches over the holiday period, just as they were in the film Jaws . 
However, Florida Program for Shark Research director George Burgess said it was unlikely the attacks were the work of one shark, adding: “This isn’t a Jaws situation.” 
He added the worst attacks were probably the work of tiger or bull sharks while the less significant ones likely to be as a result of black tip or spinner sharks. 
A number of factors are being blamed for encouraging sharks closer to the shoreline where they come into contact with humans and the attacks happen. 
Burgess said hotter than usual summer temperatures have made the sea warmer and saltier, which are conditions favoured by sharks, while more holidaymakers are hitting the coast. 
Meanwhile large shoals of herrings, a favourite food of sharks, have been spotted off the coastline 
Burgess said: “You have an unholy mix of sharks and humans in greater concentrations plus lots of bait fishes.” 
He also urged local fishermen to avoid the urge to launch their own hunting parties against the sharks, adding: “That would be nothing more than an exercise in revenge.”
